headline: Barbecue Ribs
description: A tasty rib marinade made with sweet and spicy ingredients, including rum, is poured over baked pork ribs that are grilled until smoky and tender.

video.description: The barbecue ribs recipe in this video is easier than it looks. You can cook the ribs the day before and grill them for a quick dinner the next night. Enjoy this classic at a tailgate or any outdoor party!
video.name: Simple Country Ribs Recipe

name: Barbecue Ribs

recipeInstructions.text: Preheat the oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
Cut spareribs into serving size portions; wrap in double thickness of foil.
Bake in the preheated oven for 1 1/2 hours. Unwrap and drain drippings. (I usually freeze drippings to use later in soups.) Place ribs in a large roasting pan.

Mix together brown sugar, chile sauce, ketchup, soy sauce, Worcestershire sauce, rum, garlic, mustard, and pepper in a bowl. Coat ribs with sauce and marinate at room temperature for 1 hour or refrigerate for 8 hours to overnight.
Preheat the grill to medium heat. Position grate 4 inches above heat source; grease the grate with cooking spray.
Cook ribs on the preheated grill for 30 minutes, basting with marinade.

review.reviewBody: My first attempt at ribs. My husband loved them and so did I. Very easy recipe. I did put some garlic powder and Mrs. Dash table blend on the ribs before baking. I will make these again, many times.
Best rib recipe yet, I used spiced dark rum, yum. We save the pork broth to make pea soup. Thank you
I cooked for 4 hours on 250 degrees

I've been cooking ribs for 50+ years and this without a doubt the best recipe I've found on line. Excluding Korean, Hawaiian and other "themed" type recipes this is #1 in my book. You can use southern comfort in place of rum. I'm going to use this for 30 pounds of ribs I'm making for a celebration of life gathering in honor for our son and I expect the same greatvrrdukts I always get. My only change is that I place an entire slab on heavy duty foil and season it with dried minced onions and garlic and seasoned salt and cook it at 275 for a couple of hours the drain the juices off and put them on the marinade for 24 hrs. I put the drained juices I'm a bowl and put it in the freezer so the fat solidifies and can be easily removed. Then I save the rest of the flavored juice to add to BBQ sauces. It adds great flavor.

Many years later and still making it, for my 2 cents worth, in my circle of friends, we are concerned with aluminum products in relation to cooking and food and the studies made to the close relation to Alzheimer's and aluminum, for this reason there are no aluminum products in our kitchen, when aluminum is heated above a certain temperature it releases aluminum oxide the whitish powder it forms, this is the bad one to ingest, so we look for alternatives. Boiling the ribs, when i spoke to people about this, it became apparent it's been done this way for hundreds of years around the world, I've done it both ways, boil and oven, the boiling method is superior to other methods because a lot of the fat is boiled off and the flavors are re-introduced by marinating, great recipe.

I made this per the recipe except for using only 3/4 cup of sugar. Marinated the ribs overnight in the sauce after baking. They came out pretty good. This recipe brings out more of the meat's flavor with the sauce being a nice accent. There is more meat flavor because the ribs are precooked in the oven instead of being boiled. If you like your ribs falling apart before you get them to the grill or if you like ooey-gooey ribs with a thick slathering of sweet sauce, this recipe is definitely not for you. If you want more of the meat flavor to come through with only a touch of sauce flavor and accent, this is the recipe. After baking, the ribs are still solid and easy to move to the grill after marinating and for serving after grilling.
Excellent recipe. Marinade was fantastic and ribs were cooked perfectly.

Soooooo easy and soooooo good!!! I followed another reviewer’s recommendation and boiled the ribs on low for 2 hours, then marinated in the sauce overnight. While they were on the grill for 30 mins (15 mins each side), I simmered the remaining marinade down to a thick sauce and poured over the ribs when they were done. The meat was super tender and the sauce was finger licking good!!! Will make this over and over and over.
Our Go To BBQ Ribs ... We substitute Laphroaig (High Peat Scotch) for the rum.
WOW GREAT RIBS!!

I made this recipe exactly as written & served them to company. Rave reviews all the way around! 2 of the 4 at the table are not rib lovers but said they would definitely eat these again. Thank you so much for the recipe! I have always boiled my ribs prior to grilling/putting them in oven but I didn't ever think to add the bbq sauce &, I must say, it makes them even better.

I loved everything about this recipe and so easy to make! Easy to cook in the oven and then the added on-the-grill finish perfected it. The sauce flavor was just the right intensity. I recommend that when on the individual plates where you cut up the rack to single ribs, that you have a side of the sauce to coat the newly exposed cuts otherwise you lose a bit of the sauce flavor. The whole family raved over this recipe and we will make it again many times.

We’ve made these a couple of times now- best recipe we’ve found- they come out so tender and fall right off the bones. We have used store bought bbq sauce one of the times because we were so busy and they came out amazing as well. A great all around rib recipe- oh, and grill them at the end of at all possible- we grill corn at the same time and it’s all done at once! So easy! Very happy with this recipe and will be using it for many years!
Love this recipe. I put my ribs in my pressure cooker. Removed them from pressure cooker and finished them off on the barbecue. Basting the ribs in the sauce. Soooooooo good
So good. Made as instructed. Turned out perfectly.
Simmer the extra sauce for dipping!
Followed the recipe as written. It was amazing!! New Favorite!!

I didn't leave time for marinating for 1 hour, so I skipped that step. I wrapped and baked them for 1 1/2 hours, then put them right on the grill and basted them with sauce while grilling. They were wonderful, even skipping that step. Next time (and, yes there will be a next time!) I'll take time for marinading. I don't know how they could be better, but I'll give it a try!

I’ve never reviewed a recipe, but man... My wife and son and I devoured these. I made a few changed as needed. I didn’t have chile sauce so I used 1/3 cup ketchup and ¼ cup yellow sriracha. 
 I boiled the ribs(refrigerated, not frozen) gently for 30 minutes with a little liquid smoke. While they cooled, I prepared the marinade. Poured marinade into a gallon freezer bag with the ribs. Into a bowl, into the fridge. 
 I left out the brown sugar for the first day of marinating, and on the second I added the sugar, dissolved in 1 cup of water, to the marinade. 
 On the third day(grilling day), I pulled the ribs out of the marinade and set them in a bowl to get up to room temp. Put the marinade in a small saucepan to reduce it. Lit up the charcoal grill, and got it up to about 350°F. Put the ribs in a lightly-oiled cast iron pan, covered the pan with foil, and baked them on the grill for about 20 minutes. Finished the ribs over indirect heat on the grill; no basting, extra seasoning, etc. 
 Sauce reduced down a good bit, but I brought it back to a quick boil And added arrowroot to thicken it a little. Liberally doused the ribs with the sauce— this stuff came out AMAZINGLY. 
 Ribs were tender, slightly-caramelized, and not “fall-off-the-bone”. The meat held on just enough for easy eating. 
 I’ve been all around this world and these might be THE greatest ribs I’ve ever had. 
 Thanks for sharing this recipe, and for commenters’ ideas on boiling the ribs.
I added some honey to help thicken it and it was great!

This is a nice recipe I didn’t have chili sauce so I added a couple of Tablespoons hot chipotle instead, also cooked at 250 degrees for 4 hours, came out excellent falling off the bone, no photo as after smelling that cook couldn’t wait to eat it.
I boiled the ribs and then let them sit in the marinade all day. Baked and basted and the sauce is amazing! This recipe is a keeper!
My favorite!
Excellent! And love the ability to make ahead!

Great sauce and tender! I really only used the sauce as I boiled the ribs for an hour as suggested and then baked it at 350 degrees for an hour and finished with a 5 min broil. The sauce is great tho!
Turned out Grrreat!
Tender and tasty. I use my own homemade fruit chile sauce in this recipe.
made it without the chili sauce too and it was delish
Good and sticky ribs. I used smaller side ribs and simply reduced the time they were on the BBQ.
First time rib maker and it turned out great! Lots of compliments! Definitely will make again ...soon!

First, thanks to jimmyYX357 for convincing me not to try boiling the ribs (I was worried they’d be dry/tough as some reviewers said.) I added a few slices of lime to each foil packet and made sure to seal the foil up tight. They came out moist and tender.

The sauce phenomenal ... just make a side note that the baking process (90 minutes) is a relative time and to wait (because of variances in thickness) that time to be extended until the meat begins to withdraw from the bone more than just a little)

Couldn't find chile sauce used 1/2 ground chili paste (spicy) and half chili sauce. I cooked the ribs an extra 30 min. in the oven and they were tender, Put on outside grill and it only took 15 min.; had a hot fire, watch the sugar can burn easily.
The best tasting barbeque ever! I didn't have any dry mustard, so I used regular mustard. I used minced garlic instead of cloves. Thos recipe will be used for a lifetime. So Amazing & delicious!
Hubby fussy on good ribs - and he loved these! Will make again!
#1 have been following this recipe for years! Top Notch!
I used Tequila instead of Rum!

We marinated these overnight, good recipe easy to use.
Would prefer a little more “bite”

This was sooo good! I love that this isn't just typical ribs with bbq sauce (SNOOZE). I'm not a huge fan of spicy food, so I left out the chili sauce, and the marinade/glaze was still absolutely delicious. To think, I was about to delete this recipe before making it too. I'm so glad I didn't!

However I have made some changes. I use Huy Fong chili sauce which already has tons of garlic. So I don't add more garlic. Also you don't need quite as much of that chili sauce. I also add some ginger. Also when pre cooking the ribs I cook at 225 for 6 hours.
Great! Used 1/4 cup of sriracha sauce and 1/4 cup of pimento sauce instead of the chili sauce.
I didn't make any changes. Absolutely wonderful recipe.
Amazing!

I’ve been making this consistently for about two years now. It is by far the best recipe I have ever used. Whenever I deviate to try something else my husband will say “next time can we just go back to your awesome rib recipe?” Haha, guess what’s for supper tonight?!
Our new favorite! Easy to follow recipe with outstanding results.

I have been making this recipe for over 5 years now and thought I posted a review but oh well, here goes! Thank you! Thank you! Thank you! I made it as instructed but after marinating the ribs and chicken, I thicken the sauce with a cornstarch and voila... it's now my sauce. It's been a big hit every time.

Another winner. I made these one night and didn’t say anything about the recipe. My better-half asked what BBQ sauce I put on them and what else I did (she knows I tweak things at times). I told her it was this recipe, “Those were great!” Another winner. I have already been tweaking it. Makers Mark has replaced the rum and the amount of brown sugar has been reduced.

This is the only ribs recipe that I use. It's hands down the best if you are not a big fan of BBQ sauce like me. To spice things up a little, I season the ribs before putting them in the oven. 
I heat up the leftover sauce to serve on the side. Thanks so much for sharing!
Really good!

I made these exactly as written and they were excellent. They were not exactly melt off the bone but the flavour was yummy. Maybe next time I will try boiling them rather than putting them in the oven. 
They certainly didn't need 30 mins on the grill. We cooked them until heated through and they were fine.

i cut down on the b. sugar by 1/4 cup. i didn't have chile sauce so used a sweet chili sauce . i also thickened the sauce with a bit of cornstarch. i used my own dry rub on the ribs, double foil wrapped them and baked them for 1 1/2 hrs at 300. i then drained the liquid and then brushed the ribs with the slightly thickened bbq sauce. i covered them again and baked for 1 more hour at 285. very tender. will make again.
New favourite recipe, they turned out amazing
Great recipe.
way too little tomato base!!!! added loads of puree to help but the whole thing is way too sour especially with the soy sauce in it.rubbish. you're better off with hp bbq sauce. disappointed.
We loved these ribs! And as one other mentioned - I too will be using the sauce on other recipes. Can't wait to try it on grilled chicken! YUM!!

These are the best ribs I have ever made. After 30 minutes in the oven, I reduced the heat to 225. After another hour (90 minutes total) I added beer and sauce to the ribs, rolled them back up and roasted another hour at 170 degrees before pulling them and letting them marinade for another hour at room temperature. They were amazing. I will be using this recipe again.

This was my third attempt at making ribs. My first with this recipe. My family loved these ribs! They were so good, the moist and tender meat fell off the bone. I did have to adjust the recipe, I didn't have rum. I used maple syrup and a little simple syrup in place of the rum. Next time I am going to double the recipe!!! Delicious!!
Follow the instructions to the tee, they are right on, the best way to do ribs. Thanks
The sauce is delicious! We will definitely make them again
This receipe is so easy and the taste is DELICIOUS....will definity make this a staple !
I did the boil method - simmered them for 1 hour and 20 minutes. Used sriracha for the chile sauce. they turned out awesome with i nice spicy kick
Very good. Will add brown sugar,ketchup and dry mustard. Instead of rum I used pineapple juice.

I made it just the way it was written, except when I got home I realized all I had was Malibu coconut rum liqueur. It still got rave reviews and was requested again. I am making them again today, so I'm not changing what I did last time.

Excellent recipe!!! Super tender and flavorful ribs. Made a few substitutions simply because all the ingredients weren't available in the pantry. For example, in place of rum, I used shoyu, molasses and vanilla extract. To ensure the ribs were tender I doused each quarter rib cut with vinegar before enveloping in foil and baking.

Great recipe! And so easy. We baked them with some dry rub. Took them out, covered with the sauce and let them sit in the fridge for a couple of hours. Then we baked for another 30 minutes in the foil, the last ten, we opened the foil. These were a hit with the whole family.
I boiled the ribs. It was great. However, 4 pounds is not enough for six people. I would double the recipe.

Absolutely the best ribs I have eaten in a long time! And others said the same ... I made 16 pounds of spareribs using this recipe for a 4th of July BBQ party and followed the recipe (x 4) with only the following two exceptions:
1. Used 1/8 c. soy sauce and 1/8 c. A1 sauce in place of the Worcestershire sauce
2. Used 1/4 c. Franks Red Hot sauce and 1/4 c. KC Masterpiece BBQ sauce in place of the Chile sauce
Super easy and Super good !!!
Wow, these were really good.

The sauce is great. Yes I would agree it's not a typical BBQ sauce type flavor, more subtle. But we loved it. I gave this 4 stars not 5 because for a fall off the bone type of experience you need to really cook these low and slow. We do not boil our ribs and on the grill or in the oven you need to cook these for hours.

Didn't have any chili sauce, so used an asian chili paste. Gave it a nice zing! Best barbecue sauce I have ever had. 
Can't comment on the ribs in this recipe. I made baby back, marinated them overnight in this sauce, then cooked them at 250 for 5 hours wrapped in foil. Throw on the grill with more sauce for about 10-12 minutes. MMMMMMM!

Amazing recipe. I didn't have any ribs, so I used chicken thighs. I breaded them in a mixture of buttermilk, fresh dill, flour, and egg whites. I then fried them and served with fresh, homestyle-biscuits. I highly recommend this recipe.
Best bbq ribs period! I used bottled sauce instead of ketchup and prepared mustard. No better recipe out there!
We love this we did make a couple of small changes to fit us but this is great.
Delicious! Didn't have any rum so I left it out but the ribs still turned out great! Used the marinade for some pork chops too and they turned out wonderful. Will definitely use this marinade often.

I did a little experiment with these ribs. I had a houseful of people, so I made a batch exactly as written here; and the second batch I made in the crockpot (browning in the oven first, as described in Crockpot Ribs found on this site). I used this sauce on all the ribs. They all tasted totally awesome, thanks to this incredible sauce. They all voted the crockpot prepared ribs to be the absolute best, though. Both batches I ended up basting more sauce on the ribs and grilling in order to carmelize them. I love the ooey gooeyness of the carmelized sauce. Just want to point out, the is the BEST SAUCE ever!!!
Instead of chili and rum I added a Dr. Pepper and let it marinade overnight. Amazing !

Iv'e been making this recipe for over a decade. My son DEMANDS these for all special occasions. I season the ribs with garlic and onion powder, salt and pepper, and Beau Monde Seasoning. I bake the ribs at 320 for 2 hours. Make the sauce as the recipe directs with extra garlic and I use Dark Rum. Depending on my mood I'll use hot sauce, Liquid Smoke, mesquite seasoning, cinnamon or any thing else which catches my eye in the cupboard. I marinate over night in a tub that allows me to flip the contents upside down for full coverage. Then put the ribs on the grill on low until the marinade caramelizes on the ribs. I can't imagine boiling the ribs. My wife had a get together with appetizers only but needed a protein because of the cocktails being served. So I went to the butcher and had him cut the ribs cross ways to make the ribs more of a finger food. It worked perfectly for her needs.

HA!! Our family has been making these for years! We call them RUM RIBS and use Dark rum, preferably, or Amber. Our recipe calls for Chile Sauce OR Hot Salsa, which is what I use since I seldom have Chile Sauce on hand.
Another option is to put all in a slow cooker on High for 4 hours, drain, defat the sauce, then boil it to thicken. (Can do all this in advance, so it's all quick and easy at dinnertime). Brush with sauce to glaze under a quick broiler or barbecue. Delish.
Great dish. Wifey said it tasted like a restaurant.
Delicious! It is our family's go-to recipe. I will never purchase bottled bbq sauce again.

Never made ribs before. Easy recipe to follow and they turned out amazingly good. Everyone loved them. Definitely did not need more than 30 minutes on the grill. I had it at 350 F. Also I marinated overnight in a ziplock bag and then removed from fridge 2 hours before grilling. So if I can do it so can anyone else.

I simmered my ribs in seasoned water (onion, lemon, salt, pepper corns and thyme) for 2 hours. I put them on the grill with no sauce until just about 15 minutes before they were ready. Then I basted each side twice when flipping. The sauce was SO good! I didn't have rum, so I subbed Apple Whisky and let me just say.....WOW! The apple went so well with the pork and I loved the kick in this recipe. I also cooked the sauce to make sure the alcohol cooked out a bit so it didn't overpower it. Thanks for sharing!

My husband gave me the biggest compliment on these ribs. He said they were better then the ribs he gets at the local favorite rib and chicken restaurant. 
He wants me to make these for our friends at our bar-b-que. 
Definitely making these again!

I made it exactly as written. I baked early in the day and put in fridge with sauce over them. It was late when we barbequed the ribs so they did marinate a while. They were absolutely the best ribs I ever ate. So delicious I'll dream about them until we fix them again, I'm planning a cook out with family just so I can have them again!
Best ribs I've ever made. So good
Just made this. It was fantastic!!! My whole family was in heaven. Only thing I can think of to make it better is double the whole recipe! Thank you!

This is the only recipe my husband will use now. It is delicious and everyone who has the ribs, loves them. I've read some who say there's a difference between chili and chile sauce. I'm sure there is. But we use "chili" sauce and really don't care whether it is the right one or not, as the BBQ sauce is fantastic with it. Make this recipe with confidence; it's a keeper!

I don't agree with boiling the ribs, I prefer this recipe as is, boiling the meet does make it a bit more tender but in the foil pack they steam in their own juice and you have more flavor, I opt for the flavor versus the tenderness. I have used this recipe for years and will keep it as is.
One word: Delicious!
Boiled and only marinated for few hours and they were best tasting ribs ever
My first time making ribs ever!! Boiled in smoke, made own sauce and OMG!!!! Wow!!! Thank you everyone for all the great ideas.

I did wrap my ribs and bake, but not at the temperatures and times in the recipes. I also rubbed my ribs with salt, pepper, onion and garlic powders. I also did not marinate with the sauce before finishing them off. Instead I put some sauce in the bottom of my baking sheet, then topped the back side of the ribs with the sauce and baked at about 350 for 15 minutes, stopping every 5 minutes to reapply sauce. Then I flipped and did the same for the top side of the ribs. The sauce soaked in very nicely and also created a nice glaze like we all like. The sauce itself was excellent. It cooked out really nice and flavorful. My only thing that gave me pause at all about this sauce is that the soy sauce gave it a bit of a teriyaki flavor, which is ok. The recipe calls for chile sauce with an e, and some are interpreting this as chili sauce, which of course is sweet. I instead used 1/2 sriracha sauce and 1/2 Frank's Red Hot. I think next time I would use perhaps 2/3 sriracha and 1/3 chili sauce. Excellent overall recipe and I will make this again. Thank you!

Not having any rum on hand, I chose to make the sauce with whiskey instead and it turned out delicious! Care should be used when grilling, especially over real coals, as the high sugar content can add to the risk of surface burning.
This recipe is INSANE!!! I swear these ribs were just as good if not better than eating out! The taste was phenomenal!!! Unbelievably good! Definitely a keeper!!

I can't make this often enough! Easy instructions- just be sure to use Chile sauce (not chili). I like Herdez Roasted Pasilla Chile. It's NOT spicy. I let my cooked ribs sit over night in Recipes sauce before heating on grill. I reserve the excess sauce and simmer it in pan to use for dipping the ribs. Outstanding!
was not worth the trouble
Loved it! A keeper
Fabulous! I love everything about this recipe. Everyone loved it and i was a hit!

Modified the recipe a bit over the past few years. I use baby back ribs instead of spare ribs. Season the ribs with Montreal Steak Seasoning before baking and bake for 2 hours with them wrapped in tinfoil. With the sauce I sub out the rum with apple juice. I make these all the time and never had any leftovers.
